EROM Litchfeldto New Yor.s--by Steam 1 Boat John Marshall-through in one day-fare SS l-s-hy line stages, to meet the boat at Norwalk-leavihg Litchfeld Mon- days, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 2 A. M. through W0Odbory, Newtown and Bridge port and New-York. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. at 2 A. M. for Litchfeld, un- til the 1st May--aiter that at A. M. 6m4e

m0nthIy.concert of prayer, they admitted the first converts of their mission to the church. The.persons received were. European lady of distinction and intelligence, of the Latin church: and two Armenians, DionEsiOuS Cur 06et. and Gregory Wort0bet !; the former was archbishop in Jerusalem, the latter formerly Secretary to the patriarch. They expected to admit others in February.-At tie com mencement of this year, AsGQd ShidiGk was still in bonds for the testimony of Jesus. He is of the Maronite chnrch. These four to- gether with Jacob an Armenian, Mir. Good ell reckons as converts, who have given eyl- dence of piety for a considerable time.-Mr. G. names as inqairerS. more or less prOmis- ing, Moria, wife of DiQpysus Carabet, an Ar snenian, Susaanah Lset1sfy, wife of Gregory Wortabet, Ge Catholic church; Joseph Le- .jIufy,brOther of the proceeding, same church, andnOw superintendent of all the mission schools; Asnud Jacob, Greek church, 1Grneos, the mission schoolmaster at BeyrOot, Greek church Pho7es, brother of Asaad Shidiak, MarOnite church, sent to Malta for the pres ervation of his life. There are also several ;ndivid0als, both of the Maronite and the Greek church, who come to read the scrip ture and converse, and are convinced of the errors oftheir own churches. These make aAtotal of about twenty; besides many who see that the Bible is right and they are wrong

 General State of the Mission.-In Noyeln- ber, MT, G.. wrote, "The number of those, who come to read with IS every evening, is increasing. The largest room in my house is sometimes well filed; and as few of them find it inconvenient to return home the same evening, have provided beds for them. They usually sit~up more than half the night, cOnveTsing, on what they have seen and heard.

 In January last he wrote, 'sOur prospects daily brighten, through opposition to us con- tinually increases. There is much comn1o- ton, and great noise; and such are the de- mands made upon eur time, that we are sometimes compelled to go without our regu- lar meals, and our usual sleep. .--A Almost every thing seems to lend towards terrible con- flict between sChiist and Anticnrist."

 .Schools--s. Thirteen schools had been es- tablished, which contained about sir kMad-, red children, of acheaa more ihon one hundred are GIRLs.n &

 IHe Press at Malto.-The Editors of the Herald say, "The printing establishment at Malta, is continually risang in importance and interest. Two presses are in Operotion IA printer, MT. HailOck, has been sent from this country, and has entered upon his work with becoming zeal. MT. Temple ls able to superintend the press in ItdliGH and Modern Greek. A fount of Arabic types, is about to be procured, and Mr. Smith has gone to E. :gypt and Syria, for season, to prepare him. self tu take charge of the Arabic Press; and lately, as was stated at the close of the bio- graphical notices of Asaad Shidiak, young man of good promise, has been sent to Malta, to secure his liberty and life against the hos tile attempts of his prosecuting Countrymen {; and will be able te render valuable assistance in the Arabic department.--The following ex- tract from Mir. Goodell's correspondence, a. wakens the expectation that Providecnce will very soon prepare the way for the erection of an AqaeRids Press, also, at Malta"

 Furious Notices.--Phares, the youngest brother of Asaad Shidiak~ appears exceeding ly well, ready to suffer the loss of all things for Christ. O it is good to see the spirits of the martyrs reviving here

 r.s It is now pretty certain, that there is a firman against the two Armenians with me, (DionysiHs and Wotarbet J but MT. Abbot, the consul is very positive that they are quite safe in my house. We all think it best, how ever, to send Wortabet to Malta, should a fla vorable opportunity occur. He will there be out of danger; he can learn English to better advantage, than here; and when the Armen- ian press arrives, his service will be wanted to correct the proof sheets. We have great hopes of his future usefulness.'

 INTERESTING LETTER

 From the Sandscich lslGnds Mission, to the Assistant Secretary, published in the Boston Daily Aduertissr.

 ToHAIGH BAY, GOs0hyhee,) Nov. 8, 1928.

 My DEAR RRoTHER,-I snatch few mo- ments this evening to improve an opportunity that offers to send to America by way of Wo- ahoo, in writing nasty letter to you, my dis tant brother.

 We have. oflate, been priviledged by a visit from several of the chiefs of the Leeward isl- ands, who we hope belong to the kingdom of our Lord. They spent month or upwards at Kiruah and vicinity, where we have been gratified and encouraged by their example and inilnenee in behalf of religion. 06e feet of their visit is to extend the Knowledge of Christ and his Gospel to all their people i; and to prepare them for the reception of a code of Christian laws. In the prosecution of this object, they have come hither, where are assembled the whole people, inhabiting Kohula and Hamakua to receive the laws which are about to be pablished. have also improved the occasion to follow them in or der to preach the Gospel to the many thou sands here collected. I arrived here this morning ina canoe, having left my home yes ferday, and hoped to be enabled to preach to the peoR)s daily until my return.

 MT. Rinn ham and family still rc,nain af

E TONS good HAY ,-one span good low price O Team HORSESs good Lumber Wagon and Harness.

 Also, to contract fo 1900 Casks LIME, to be burnt after the middle of September. Goods will be advan. ced before hand and Some money on the delivery of the Lime. E. H. DENISON.

 Norfolk June 9, 1S27. 4w52

THE Court of Probate for the District of u Litch6eld hath assigned the 18th day of instant June, at nine o'clock in the forenoon, at the Probate Office in Litchfeld, for the appointment of Commissioners on the estate of ASAPH WRIGHT, late of Goshen, in said district. deceased, rep- resented insolvent; at which time and place all persons interested in said estate will, if they see cause, attend before said court, and he heard respecting such appointment. By order of said court,

 SILAS P. WRIGHT, ]

 EDWARD WRIGHT, ao~..n.s- ~.

 GEORGE COOK, ''a'o's' Goshen, June 2, 1897. 51
NOTICE.

CONANT CATLIN,

 ELIAS w. WILLIAMS.
NOTICE.

or hf Mauis For several days In succession they prosecuted their search through the village for women, breaking into houses, and taking away the property of the inofensiye inhabit- ants. who looked on without assaulting them because their chiefs were gtne, who. should lead them. They bore the spelling of their goods with fortitude knowing it was for righ- eousness' sake that they were called to suffer: but they yielded not an inch in complying with the demands of the ships; and the sail ors at last abandoned their search, and hir- ed their captains to take them to Woahoo, in h hopes of getting women there. This is hut specirnine of the abuse and insult that inc mission is daily receiving from our own cOun- trymen and other foreigners, who leave no means untried to bring into discredit, not only us, hut all who profess to have become piOus.

 The principal spite of foreigners is levelled against our dear brother and fellow laborer, MT. Bingham: but you may be assured, that the brethren consider it common cause, and equally as much against the whole body as a. gainst him; and we feel 1t to be our duty publicly to give him and his measures, so far as they have come to our knOwlege, our deci- ded appreciation.

 Sabbath evening NoU. 5.

 I have just returned from the service of this day. where have preached twice to congregation of more then fen MouS1nd listen ing hearers. They were assembled in coca- nut grove, and delivered my message to them in open air.-The stiffness of this inn mense multitude the solemn occasion upon which we had met; the thought that all this people would pass into eternity in the lapse of few years; gave a solemnity and an inter- est to the scene. which have seldom felt. The Lord help me to speak as one standing between the two worlds,-as an ambassador of reconciliation between God and his fallen creature man, revealing to him covenant of grace.

 5 It is a truly interesting and pleasant. service tobe the messenger of peace to perishing immortals; and, in q special manner, this the persuasion, that those, fer whose good we are iabouring, are anxiously desirous of the light and knowledge that lead to salvation. Such, my brother, is the state of this peo- pie. There was never, perhaps, a time when the prospect of complete success to our en- terprize was greater than at present. Could y0h but witness, for one day, the order, the attention, the anxious, eager look, and ob- serve the tear start from the eye of the tawny sun-burnt savage, and the countenance of hope and joy as he casts his eye upward to heaven upon hearing the terms of pardoning mercy proclaimed to him, your heart would leap for joy, and you would give God thanks for hsrisg puf ;be tile hearts of.aaE to come over the wHs Waste. of water that divides Iis, to preach salvation to this people, who hayal. long been sitting in darkness and the shadoa of death. kT

 But must leave you here, as the messea ger waits to carry this to Woabao eaa' 'Remem Der me affectionately to al! my Christian friends in Boston, assure them of the undi- unfinished regard which and Mrs. Bishop still feel towards them, and of the happiness which we enjoy in the blessed work in which we are engaged.-Adieu.

 Yours affectionately, in the best bonds,

 ARTEMAs BISHOP.

 From ZScss Herald.

 4 tender scene.-A minister of the LordI Jesus once called together the elders of a church that he had gathered from the world. He was about to leave them, and the impress sion was strong on his mind that he should never see his beloved people again on earth. None hut child of God can conceive the sublimity of feeling that pervaded scene like this. Memory traverses the past, fingers moment over each fond incident, and recalls every tender association. This scene resem- ] les death, because it is a separation, and be- cause the same solemn mOurnfulness of the heart is called into action that death awakens. This minister of Jesus stood in the midst of the aged and venerable of the church, and made this affectionate address :-

 Since have been with you, u,beloved breth- -ren, you have known my labours, my anxie- ties, my cares. You know my humility, the strength of the temptations that surrounded, me, and the bitter prosecutions of my ene- mics. You can testify that in my doctrines have withheld nothing calculated to do you good. have taught you in the great con- gregation and from house to house. My| doctrine has been, repentance towards God and faith towards our Lord Jesus Christi" Il am now going to distant city, where, al- though the visien of the future is clouded with uncertainty, feel assured of meeting severe trials but of one thing have no doubt -I shall never see your faces amy more. Oh, I cannot but remember how 1 have preached to you the kingdom of God, and call upon you to bear witness that upon my gar ments the blood of your immortal souls shall not ever be found in the day of judg- ment.

 Ye fathers of the church, look we'll to your selves, and tenderly remember the flock over whom the Holy Ghost hath placed you as a guard. Feed the lambs of Christ. Wolves shall prowl around and envenomed tongues shall vent their rage on you, but remem- Der that for three years l have borne the
.and with them I.ekauonOhi, whn had iha charre of the

They usually sit~up more than half the night, cOnveTsing, on what they have seen and heard.

 In January last he wrote, 'sOur prospects daily brighten, through opposition to us con- tinually increases. There is much comn1o- ton, and great noise; and such are the de- mands made upon eur time, that we are sometimes compelled to go without our regu- lar meals, and our usual sleep. .--A Almost every thing seems to lend towards terrible con- flict between sChiist and Anticnrist."

 .Schools--s. Thirteen schools had been es- tablished, which contained about sir kMad-, red children, of acheaa more ihon one hundred are GIRLs.n &

 IHe Press at Malto.-The Editors of the Herald say, "The printing establishment at Malta, is continually risang in importance and interest. Two presses are in Operotion IA printer, MT. HailOck, has been sent from this country, and has entered upon his work with becoming zeal. MT. Temple ls able to superintend the press in ItdliGH and Modern Greek. A fount of Arabic types, is about to be procured, and Mr. Smith has gone to E. :gypt and Syria, for season, to prepare him. self tu take charge of the Arabic Press; and lately, as was stated at the close of the bio- graphical notices of Asaad Shidiak, young man of good promise, has been sent to Malta, to secure his liberty and life against the hos tile attempts of his prosecuting Countrymen {; and will be able te render valuable assistance in the Arabic department.--The following ex- tract from Mir. Goodell's correspondence, a. wakens the expectation that Providecnce will very soon prepare the way for the erection of an AqaeRids Press, also, at Malta"

 Furious Notices.--Phares, the youngest brother of Asaad Shidiak~ appears exceeding ly well, ready to suffer the loss of all things for Christ. O it is good to see the spirits of the martyrs reviving here

 r.s It is now pretty certain, that there is a firman against the two Armenians with me, (DionysiHs and Wotarbet J but MT. Abbot, the consul is very positive that they are quite safe in my house. We all think it best, how ever, to send Wortabet to Malta, should a fla vorable opportunity occur. He will there be out of danger; he can learn English to better advantage, than here; and when the Armen- ian press arrives, his service will be wanted to correct the proof sheets. We have great hopes of his future usefulness.'

 INTERESTING LETTER

 From the Sandscich lslGnds Mission, to the Assistant Secretary, published in the Boston Daily Aduertissr.

 ToHAIGH BAY, GOs0hyhee,) Nov. 8, 1928.

 My DEAR RRoTHER,-I snatch few mo- ments this evening to improve an opportunity that offers to send to America by way of Wo- ahoo, in writing nasty letter to you, my dis tant brother.

 We have. oflate, been priviledged by a visit from several of the chiefs of the Leeward isl- ands, who we hope belong to the kingdom of our Lord. They spent month or upwards at Kiruah and vicinity, where we have been gratified and encouraged by their example and inilnenee in behalf of religion. 06e feet of their visit is to extend the Knowledge of Christ and his Gospel to all their people i; and to prepare them for the reception of a code of Christian laws. In the prosecution of this object, they have come hither, where are assembled the whole people, inhabiting Kohula and Hamakua to receive the laws which are about to be pablished. have also improved the occasion to follow them in or der to preach the Gospel to the many thou sands here collected. I arrived here this morning ina canoe, having left my home yes ferday, and hoped to be enabled to preach to the peoR)s daily until my return.

 MT. Rinn ham and family still rc,nain af

THE Court of Probate for the District of u Litch6eld hath assigned the 18th day of instant June, at nine o'clock in the forenoon, at the Probate Office in Litchfeld, for the appointment of Commissioners on the estate of ASAPH WRIGHT, late of Goshen, in said district. deceased, rep- resented insolvent; at which time and place all persons interested in said estate will, if they see cause, attend before said court, and he heard respecting such appointment. By order of said court,

full articles.headline: .and with them I.ekauonOhi, whn had iha charre of the
full articles.article:
or hf Mauis For several days In succession they prosecuted their search through the village for women, breaking into houses, and taking away the property of the inofensiye inhabit- ants. who looked on without assaulting them because their chiefs were gtne, who. should lead them. They bore the spelling of their goods with fortitude knowing it was for righ- eousness' sake that they were called to suffer: but they yielded not an inch in complying with the demands of the ships; and the sail ors at last abandoned their search, and hir- ed their captains to take them to Woahoo, in h hopes of getting women there. This is hut specirnine of the abuse and insult that inc mission is daily receiving from our own cOun- trymen and other foreigners, who leave no means untried to bring into discredit, not only us, hut all who profess to have become piOus.

 The principal spite of foreigners is levelled against our dear brother and fellow laborer, MT. Bingham: but you may be assured, that the brethren consider it common cause, and equally as much against the whole body as a. gainst him; and we feel 1t to be our duty publicly to give him and his measures, so far as they have come to our knOwlege, our deci- ded appreciation.

 Sabbath evening NoU. 5.

 I have just returned from the service of this day. where have preached twice to congregation of more then fen MouS1nd listen ing hearers. They were assembled in coca- nut grove, and delivered my message to them in open air.-The stiffness of this inn mense multitude the solemn occasion upon which we had met; the thought that all this people would pass into eternity in the lapse of few years; gave a solemnity and an inter- est to the scene. which have seldom felt. The Lord help me to speak as one standing between the two worlds,-as an ambassador of reconciliation between God and his fallen creature man, revealing to him covenant of grace.

 5 It is a truly interesting and pleasant. service tobe the messenger of peace to perishing immortals; and, in q special manner, this the persuasion, that those, fer whose good we are iabouring, are anxiously desirous of the light and knowledge that lead to salvation. Such, my brother, is the state of this peo- pie. There was never, perhaps, a time when the prospect of complete success to our en- terprize was greater than at present. Could y0h but witness, for one day, the order, the attention, the anxious, eager look, and ob- serve the tear start from the eye of the tawny sun-burnt savage, and the countenance of hope and joy as he casts his eye upward to heaven upon hearing the terms of pardoning mercy proclaimed to him, your heart would leap for joy, and you would give God thanks for hsrisg puf ;be tile hearts of.aaE to come over the wHs Waste. of water that divides Iis, to preach salvation to this people, who hayal. long been sitting in darkness and the shadoa of death. kT

 But must leave you here, as the messea ger waits to carry this to Woabao eaa' 'Remem Der me affectionately to al! my Christian friends in Boston, assure them of the undi- unfinished regard which and Mrs. Bishop still feel towards them, and of the happiness which we enjoy in the blessed work in which we are engaged.-Adieu.

 Yours affectionately, in the best bonds,

 ARTEMAs BISHOP.

 From ZScss Herald.

 4 tender scene.-A minister of the LordI Jesus once called together the elders of a church that he had gathered from the world. He was about to leave them, and the impress sion was strong on his mind that he should never see his beloved people again on earth. None hut child of God can conceive the sublimity of feeling that pervaded scene like this. Memory traverses the past, fingers moment over each fond incident, and recalls every tender association. This scene resem- ] les death, because it is a separation, and be- cause the same solemn mOurnfulness of the heart is called into action that death awakens. This minister of Jesus stood in the midst of the aged and venerable of the church, and made this affectionate address :-

 Since have been with you, u,beloved breth- -ren, you have known my labours, my anxie- ties, my cares. You know my humility, the strength of the temptations that surrounded, me, and the bitter prosecutions of my ene- mics. You can testify that in my doctrines have withheld nothing calculated to do you good. have taught you in the great con- gregation and from house to house. My| doctrine has been, repentance towards God and faith towards our Lord Jesus Christi" Il am now going to distant city, where, al- though the visien of the future is clouded with uncertainty, feel assured of meeting severe trials but of one thing have no doubt -I shall never see your faces amy more. Oh, I cannot but remember how 1 have preached to you the kingdom of God, and call upon you to bear witness that upon my gar ments the blood of your immortal souls shall not ever be found in the day of judg- ment.

 Ye fathers of the church, look we'll to your selves, and tenderly remember the flock over whom the Holy Ghost hath placed you as a guard. Feed the lambs of Christ. Wolves shall prowl around and envenomed tongues shall vent their rage on you, but remem- Der that for three years l have borne the
